Box 903, New York, NY 10276-0903, USA   Email:        Phone:   +971 (0)2 6284162   Field of Study:   Atlantic World   Areas of Research/Interest:   Germany; Modern European Intellectual History; Global French Revolution; History of Emotions     Research Description:   His research interests include the global impact of the French Revolution and the Franco-German exchange during the Revolutionary Era, the transnational history of emotions in late 18th and 19th-century Europe, and the intersections of aesthetics, nationalism, and violence in German political culture.   Bio   Amir Minsky specializes in modern European intellectual and cultural history. Minsky has published work on German travelogues of post-revolutionary France, the French revolutionary and Napoleonic administration in the Rhineland, and the sentimentalized concept of liberty in the political philosophy of the German Enlightenment.   Fellowships/Honors:   Amir is the recipient of grants and fellowships from the University of Pennsylvania, the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD), the Doris G. Quinn Foundation, and the German Historical Institute in Washington DC.   Selected Works:   “New Approaches to Emotion and Nationalism in Early 19th-Century Germany” (in preparation) “Feeling Free? The Sentimental Foundations of Political Liberty in the   German Enlightenment,” ISECS International Seminar , Collected Papers   (forthcoming, 2013). “The French Revolution and the German   Chimera,” in Julia Douthwaite, Catriona Seth, Antoinette Sol (eds.),   Teaching Representations of the French Revolution (under review by MLA). “The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly: Aesthetic Violence and Moral Principle   in the German Radicals’ Reception of the French Revolution” (in   preparation). “The   Affective Revolution: German Sentimental Travels in Post-Revolutionary   France,” in Zmanim: A Historical Quarterly , no. 100 (Dec., 2007):   100-111 [In Hebrew]. “Dorsch’s Complaint: The Exigencies of   French Administration in the Roerdépartement,” in Frederick C. Schneid   and Denise Davidson (eds.), Consortium on the Revolutionary Era   1750-1850, Selected Papers 2006 (High Point University, 2007), 226-239. Other Projects    Hebrew translation editor of Benjamin Nathans, Beyond the Pale: The Jewish Encounter with Late Imperial Russia (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2002); Hebrew edition: Mikhutz la’tkhum: ha’mifgash ha’yehudi im ha’imperia ha’rusit ha’meukheret (Jerusalem: Zalman Shazar Center, 2013)               Current Courses    Ideas into Ideologies: Nineteenth-Century German Ideas and Their Global Legacies Global Revolutions, 1789-1989 Theory and Practice of History What is Man? Assistant Teaching Professor of History, NYUAD                                                      Amir Minsky                  Assistant Teaching Professor of History                                Affiliation: NYU Abu Dhabi                           e: amir.minsky@nyu.edu                                   Biography      B.A. Tel Aviv University; Ph.D. University of Pennsylvania   Amir Minsky specializes in modern European intellectual and cultural history. His research interests include the global impact of the French Revolution and the Franco-German exchange during the Revolutionary Era, the transnational history of emotions in late 18th and 19th-century Europe, and the intersections of aesthetics, nationalism, and violence in German political culture.   Minsky has published work on German travelogues of post-revolutionary France, the French revolutionary and Napoleonic administration in the Rhineland, and the sentimentalized concept of liberty in the political philosophy of the German Enlightenment.   He is the recipient of grants and fellowships from the University of Pennsylvania, the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD), the Doris G. Quinn Foundation, and the German Historical Institute in Washington DC.                                       Current Courses     Ideas into Ideologies: Nineteenth-Century German Ideas and Their Global Legacies   Global Revolutions, 1789-1989   Theory and Practice of History   What is Man?
